repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: There are no events for start and end of macro replaying,  although there are ones for recording.

Using `reg_executing()` to condition code on whether something is being executed inside a macro is not always possible. For example, if that code is executed inside a mapping which should not be executed inside a macro in the first place. Having that mapping deleted on new `MacroEnter` and restored on `MacroLeave` solves this issue.

------

Solution: Add `MacroEnter` and `MacroLeave`.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +163,8 @@ return {
     LspTokenUpdate=true,
     RecordingEnter=true,
     RecordingLeave=true,
+    ReplayingEnter=true,
+    ReplayingLeave=true,

comment_data.body: Sure, I'll change that. I've just went for the symmetry with `RecordingEnter` and `RecordingLeave`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +163,8 @@ return {
     LspTokenUpdate=true,
     RecordingEnter=true,
     RecordingLeave=true,
+    ReplayingEnter=true,
+    ReplayingLeave=true,

comment_regular_data.body:
Not sure about this, but

- Should be mentioned at `:help q` and related places.
- closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/24475
@justinmk, updated names to be `ReplayEnter` and `ReplayLeave`; added "See also" to `q` and `@`.

Note: after this PR there is a new way to crash Nvim:
```vim
autocmd ReplayLeave * bwipe!
let @r = 'i'
call nvim_open_term(0, {})
call nvim_input('@r')
```
Although it is unlikely that one will do such strange things, and this crash can also be reproduced using `vim.on_key()` without this PR, and there are already several other ways to crash Terminal mode.
I think deleting buffers/windows is disallowed in some events. Perhaps we should add that restriction to these events, to start with.

> I think deleting buffers/windows is disallowed in some events. Perhaps we should add that restriction to these events, to start with.

@justinmk, do you think this should be done in this PR? Because I am not sure I have capacity to implement it reasonably well.

Rebased to solve merge conflicts.

@justinmk, any update on relevance of this particular PR?

> Note: after this PR there is a new way to crash Nvim:

Using `aucmd_defer` from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35793 should avoid that.
 
> @justinmk, any update on relevance of this particular PR?

Maximum extensibility is a goal so I suppose it's in scope.

> > @justinmk, any update on relevance of this particular PR?
> 
> Maximum extensibility is a goal so I suppose it's in scope.

Thanks, I'll refresh it tomorrow.

Opinions on naming this `MacroEnter` instead? There are currently no help tags for "replay" at all, and only one match for "replay" in repeat.txt. Vim calls the concept "recording" but "macro" is what everyone actually calls the so it seems more discoverable.

> Opinions on naming this `MacroEnter` instead? There are currently no help tags for "replay" at all, and only one match for "replay" in repeat.txt. Vim calls the concept "recording" but "macro" is what everyone actually calls the so it seems more discoverable.

Sure, I don't have strong opinions here. My reasoning was to have these events be counterparts to `Recording[Enter,Leave]` and there are several mentions of "replaying the macro":

- `:h Q` - "replay last recorded register"
- `:h macro` - "Note: The recording happens while you type, replaying the register happens as if the keys come from a mapping."
- Three other places in describing how to replay a macro.
Using `aucmd_defer()` will defer until the end of the macro, which defeats the entire point of these two autocommands.

> Using `aucmd_defer()` will defer until the end of the macro

Can we defer input processing also? 

Also, what happens if the `MacroEnter` handler itself calls a macro? Need a test for that.

Also would need tests for the `:bwipeout` and other yucky cases.

Rebased on `master` with resolved conflicts, renamed to `MacroEnter` and `MacroLeave`.

> > Using `aucmd_defer()` will defer until the end of the macro
> 
> Can we defer input processing also?

If that is a question to me, then I have absolutely no idea. The C part of the PR was a mostly trial and error with a touch of outside help.

> Also, what happens if the `MacroEnter` handler itself calls a macro? Need a test for that.
> 
> Also would need tests for the `:bwipeout` and other yucky cases.

I think those are reasonable questions, but not specific to only `Macro{Enter,Leave}`. Those are also reasonable for `Recording{Enter,Leave}` and there is no tests for that there.

If you don't mind, I am fairly uncomfortable interacting with this part of C code base. And I think writing/adjusting/interacting with tests for at least "what if there is another macro call inside an event" would require that.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

title: feat(events): add `MacroEnter` and `MacroLeave` events
